CLUE: Japanese dish, often cooked at table
OUTPUT: ['Sushi: A traditional Japanese dish made with vinegared rice and various toppings such as raw fish or vegetables.', 'Tempura: Battered and deep-fried seafood or vegetables served over a small portion of white rice, often eaten at the table in Japan.', 'Sashimi: Thinly sliced raw fish served with soy sauce, ginger, and wasabi, typically enjoyed on the side of other dishes.', 'Donburi: A variety of Japanese rice bowls topped with different ingredients such as chicken teriyaki (Yakitori Kare-Don), tuna sashimi (Tairirimono), or vegetables (Yasai donburi).', 'Nigiri: Hand-pressed raw fish over vinegared rice, usually served at the table with soy sauce and wasabi.', 'Chirashi Sushi: A bowl of sushi toppings scattered on top of a mound of seasoned rice, often eaten directly from the bowl while seated at the dining table.', 'Maki: Sushi rolls wrapped in nori (seaweed), with fillings such as fish or vegetables and served sliced into bite-size pieces on a plate.', 'Omu-soba: A hearty Japanese pancake filled with thin noodles, meat, and vegetables, typically enjoyed at the table in restaurants.', 'Unagi Don (Eel Rice Bowl): Grilled eel served over steamed white rice, often accompanied by a soy sauce-based dipping sauce to eat while seated at the dining table.', 'Tamago Kake Gohan: A simple yet delicious Japanese meal consisting of grilled or fried eggs mixed with hot steamed rice and eaten straight from the bowl, often enjoyed at home or in restaurants.', 'Yakitori: Skewered chicken cooked over charcoal and served as a stand-alone dish or alongside other side dishes at the table.', 'Shabu-shabu: A hotpot Japanese meal where thinly sliced meat, vegetables, tofu, and mushrooms are cooked in boiling liquid at the table by dipping them into the broth with fresh ingredits such as scallions or ginger.', 'Yakisoba: A flavorful Japanese stir-fried noodle dish made from wheat flour, served on a plate and eaten while seated at the table.', 'Okonomiyaki: Savory pancake filled with cabbage, meat or seafood, and other ingredients such as bacon or kimchi, cooked in front of diners at specialty restaurants.', 'Gyoza: Japanese dumplings made from a thinly wrapped mixture of ground meat (usually pork), cabbage, and rice, filled with delicious flavors, served in pairs and enjoyed directly from the plate while seated at the table.', 'Nabe (Japanese Hotpot): A steaming bowl-style hot pot dish that is commonly eaten using chopsticks or a spoon by the diners themselves at the table.', 'Soba: Noodles made from buckwheat flour, served either cold with dipping sauce (zaru soba) or as noodles in hot broths such as miso soup and simmered dishes (suimono).', 'Shabu-shabu: A Japanese teppanyaki grill meal featuring thinly sliced meat, vegetables, tofu, mushrooms, and other ingredients cooked in boiling liquid while diners stir the ingredts around using chopsticks or a fork.', 'Ramen: Noodle soup dish made from Chinese-style wheat noodles served in a meat or fish-based broth, often with toppings such as sliced pork (tonkatsu), nori, scallions, and menma (fermented bamboo shoots).', 'Udon: Thick wheat flour noodles served in a hot or cold soup, sometimes accompanied by tempura-style vegetables, seafood, or other toppings, eaten while seated at the table.']

['Average - The mean or middle value in a set of numbers, representing the general level or typical amount.', 'Norm - An established standard or rule based on what is considered normal or average within a particular context.', 'Median - The middle number in a sorted list of values; it represents an equal distribution between both ends of the dataset.', 'Mean - A statistical measure that calculates the sum of all numbers in a set and divides by the count, often referred to as arithmetic average.', 'Midpoint - The point equidistant from two extremes or limits within a range.', 'Typical - Ordinary or representative; possessing characteristics typical of something rather than exceptional or unique.', 'General - Average in nature, not specific or unusual, representing the norm for a particular group or category.', 'Conventional - Based on or conforming to generally accepted standards or practices that are considered average or normal within a context.', 'Moderate - Within reasonable limits; neither excessive nor deficient but rather average in degree or intensity.', 'Standard - An established level, amount, or quality serving as a benchmark for comparison and often considered the norm or average.', 'Average Temperature - The mean temperature over a period; typically, it represents normal weather conditions for that region.', 'Mean Score - The average score obtained from multiple assessments; often used in academics and sports performance evaluations.', 'Central Tendency - A statistical measure representing the middle or typical value within a dataset (e.g., mean, median, mode).', 'Common Factor - An element common to all subjects within a particular context that contributes to their average nature.', 'General Assortment - A collection of items that are not particularly unique but represent the norm or commonality.', 'Typical Day - The average day, representing what is considered normal for daily routines and activities.', 'Standard Deviation - A statistical measure showing how much variation there is from the mean (average) in a set of values; it quantifies dispersion around the average.', 'Balanced Diet - A diet consisting of foods that provide an appropriate balance, typically including various nutrients at amounts considered average for health and well-being.', 'Normal Range - The span or limits within which a particular measurement, such as body temperature, blood pressure, or laboratory values, is expected to fall under normal conditions.']

['Taboo - Something forbidden by social convention.', 'Ban (verb) - To prohibit officially; to impose a ban on something.', 'Edict - An official decree, often of prohibition.', 'Restriction - A limitation or restriction placed on an action or behavior.', 'Prohibition - The act of forbidding something by law.', 'Censorship - The suppression of speech or writing deemed offensive; can involve bans.', 'Sacrilege - An act considered to be a violation or misuse of what is regarded as sacred, sometimes involving prohibitions within religious contexts.', 'Heresy - Beliefs or opinions that deviate from established doctrines and often result in certain restrictions within religions.', 'Sin - A transgression against divine law; some sins have specific prohibitive stipulations tied to customs or religion.', 'Prohibited - Not allowed or legally forbidden, especially by a religious institution.', 'Interdict - An ecclesiastical ban on the exercise of an office or function.', 'Apostasy - The abandonment or renunciation of a religious belief; often comes with prohibitions within religions.', 'Blasphemy - Disrespectful language or actions considered as showing contempt towards sacred things, typically subject to customary restrictions in religion.', 'Fasting - Abstention from food and/or drink for an extended period of time; some religious traditions mandate specific fasts with certain restrictions.', 'Pilgrimage - A journey often undertaken as a devotional act, which can involve customary or prohibitive regulations in various religions.', 'Sacrament - A religious rite recognized as of particular importance and significance; some may have specific requirements that limit participation.', 'Ordinance (noun) - A piece of legislation enacted by a governmental authority, which can include prohibitions on certain practices or behaviors.', 'Decree - An official order issued by an authority; in religious contexts, it may be used to impose restrictions or customs.', 'Mandate (noun) - A formal command or authorization from a legal or regulatory body, which might include prohibitions in religious practices.', 'Consecration - The act of making something sacred; this can involve certain rituals and procedures with associated prohibitions within customs and religions.']

['Toolbox - A container for holding tools and equipment used in various tasks such as repair or construction work.', 'Drill - Power tool used to bore holes into materials like wood, metal, or concrete.', 'Hammer - Handheld device with a weighted head used for driving nails, breaking objects, or shaping metals.', 'Screwdriver - Tool used to insert and tighten screws in various materials.', 'Pliers - Hand tool designed for gripping, bending, cutting and holding objects securely.', 'Wrench - A tool with a movable jaw or opening, typically used to turn nuts and bolts.', 'Nail gun - Power-operated device that shoots fasteners such as nails into wood or other materials.', 'Saws - Various cutting tools designed for slicing through materials like wood, metal, or plastic.', 'Tape measure - A flexible ruler used to measure length and distance in construction and carpentry work.', 'Level - A tool that measures the straightness or level of a surface or object.', 'Chisel - Hand-held cutting tool with a sharp edge, usually used for shaping wood, stone, or metal.', 'Power saw - Electrically powered tool designed to cut through materials like wood, plastic, and metal.', 'Flashlight - Portable hand-held light source used for illuminating dark spaces during outdoor activities.', 'Heavy equipment - Large machines or devices used in construction such as excavators, bulldozers, and cranes.', 'Jigsaw - Power saw with a reciprocating blade designed to cut complex curves and shapes in wood or other materials.', 'Pneumatic tool - Tool powered by compressed air or gas, used for various tasks such as drilling, hammering, or cutting.', 'Impact wrench - Power tool that delivers high-torque output with minimal effort from the user.', 'Jigs - Specialized tools designed to guide another tool, ensuring accuracy and precision in manufacturing processes.', 'Jack - A lifting device used for raising or lowering heavy loads during maintenance or construction work.', 'Safety equipment - Protective gear worn by workers to reduce the risk of injury while handling equipment, such as gloves, safety glasses, ear protection, and steel-toe boots.']

['Child - A young human being, typically under the age of puberty.', 'Kiddo - An affectionate term for a child or small boy.', 'Juvenile - Pertaining to someone in their youth or early years.', 'Infant - A very young child, especially one less than a year old.', 'Toddler - A young child who is just beginning to walk and explore the world around them.', 'Youngster - An informal term for a young person or boy in his youthful stage.', 'Littlest - Describing someone as being small, especially when referring to children.', 'Youngling - A term used to refer to an immature child or young animal.', 'Youth - The time of life when one is young; also refers to a young person.', 'Sprog - An informal term for a baby or very young boy, originating from Scandinavian languages.', 'Whelp - A colloquial and sometimes derogatory term used to refer to a puppy (can be applied humorously to a child).', 'Munchkin - An informal term for a small or dainty-looking person, often whimsically used when referring to children.', 'Wee one - A cute and affectionate way of describing an infant or young boy.', 'Kid - Informally referring to a child or young boy in colloquial contexts.', 'Wriggler - An informal term for a baby or young child, often used playfully.', 'Pipsqueak - A diminutive word that can be used affectionately or slightly derogatory when referring to a small or insignificant boy.', 'Fledgling - Literally meaning a bird that has recently fledged but can also refer metaphorically to someone new in any endeavor, including young boys starting their journey in life.', 'Chickadee - An informal term for a small or youthful person, especially used humorously and affectionately among adults when referring to children.', 'Lassie - A diminutive form of the Scottish Gaelic name "Laighbhidh," which means little girl but can be playfully applied to young boys in certain contexts.', 'Pupil - Although primarily a term for someone who attends school, it is sometimes used informally when referring to a child or young boy.']
